docs.snippet: For Olatz Schnabel, living well is not about revenge....
docs.lead_paragraph: Though the artist himself might disagree, it would seem that Julian Schnabel has not been much concerned, in life, with the concept of negative space. As anyone who has ever met him, seen one of his paintings or visited one of his homes will tell you: He takes up all the space available, and more. But peel him away from the frame, and you find that what used to be the background has quieter and more intriguing virtues.
docs.abstract: For Olatz Schnabel, living well is not about revenge.

docs.snippet: 9 P.M. (ABC) ONE MOMENT IN TIME: THE LIFE OF WHITNEY HOUSTON This special edition of ''20/20'' looks at the musical legacy and rocky personal life of Ms. Houston, right, who died on Saturday. It also includes her 2002 interview with Diane Sawyer a...
docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (ABC) ONE MOMENT IN TIME: THE LIFE OF WHITNEY HOUSTON This special edition of ''20/20'' looks at the musical legacy and rocky personal life of Ms. Houston, right, who died on Saturday. It also includes her 2002 interview with Diane Sawyer and reveals developments in her final days. Other tributes include ''Whitney Houston: Last Days of a Legend,'' at 8 on E!, and ''Whitney Houston, an Icon Remembered,'' at 8 on TV Guide. Encore will broadcast two of her films: ''Waiting to Exhale'' (1995), at 8, and ''The Preacher's Wife'' (1996), at 10:05. 8:30 A.M. (USA) ATONEMENT (2007) Saoirse Ronan plays Briony, a 13-year-old aspiring playwright who accuses Robbie (James McAvoy), the son of a family servant -- and the lover of her older sister, Cecilia (Keira Knightley, above, with Mr. McAvoy) -- of a crime in this drama directed by Joe Wright and adapted by Christopher Hampton from the Ian McEwan novel. Romola Garai and Vanessa Redgrave play Briony as a young woman and as an older writer. ''The main casualty of the film's long, murky middle and end sections is the big moral theme -- and also the ingenious formal gimmick -- that provides the book with some of its intensity and much of its cachet,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''As the title suggests, 'Atonement' is fundamentally about guilt and the attempt to overcome it, and about the tricky, tragically imperfect power of art to compensate for real-life crimes and misdemeanors.'' The film received seven Oscar nominations, including one for best picture.
